thread.title: Burnie uses ginger beer as makeover for old paper mill building
thread.title_full: Burnie uses ginger beer as makeover for old paper mill building

author: Margot Kelly
title: Burnie uses ginger beer as makeover for old paper mill building
text:
By Margot Kelly Posted February 23, 2017 17:46:07 Map: Burnie 7320 
The industrial area of Burnie's old pulp and paper mill on the north-west coast of Tasmania may be on the cusp of a foodie makeover. 
Henry's Ginger Beer said demand for its product had increased so rapidly in four years it had decided to upsize and found the spacious warehouses of the disused pulp mill was the perfect spot. 
Co-owner Carolyn Watson-Paul said the history of the site will now be part of its business story. 
"I love the historic feel of this building," she said. 
"You almost have a feel of what's been here previously." 
"It used to be the old carpenter's shop in the pulp mill." New identity developing for town 
The Burnie Pulp and Paper Mill once ranked as one of the largest employers in the region, employing over 2,000 people, until it eventually shut down in 2010 due to a number of factors. 
While the 'industrial chic' aesthetic has gained traction in the suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney, in north-west Tasmania the region remains 'industrial'. 
The ginger beer brewery is nestled amongst truck repair shops and overlooks piles of woodchips on the docks, known locally as the 'Pyramids of Burnie'. Photo: Once 2,000 staff would have had their security passes checked at this gate, now it stands vacant (ABC Rural: Margot Kelly) 
But the Ms Watson-Paul and her husband Marc are part of the growing vanguard of food and beverage entrepreneurs connecting Tasmania's industrial past with its touted agri-tourism future. 
"We have plans to have a cellar door so the public can come and buy directly from us," Ms Watson-Paul said. 
"Where we were before we couldn't have a cellar door local shopkeepers were telling us there were so many people coming into town saying, 'Where is the ginger beer brewery?'" Photo: Reclaimed milk vats are being used to brew ginger beer (ABC Rural: Margot Kelly) 
Even the production line is evidence of the intersection of industry and agriculture, with reclaimed dairy technology used to brew the ginger beer. 
"Because we started off with a very small budget, we start finding disused equipment from the dairy industry. 
"Most of our ginger beer is brewed in large milk vats," Ms Watson-Paul said. 
"Then we pasteurise it to prevent fermentation," he said.
